title: Political Cartoon by Jim Berryman, "Down by the Station"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jim Berryman showing President Harry S. Truman and Governor Thomas E. Dewey on their respective campaign trains, riding through a desert. Truman's train is entitled the "Give 'Em Hell Special" and Dewey's is entitled the "Brotherly Love" special. In this photo, the cartoon is titled, "Down by the Station." When it was originally published in the Washington Evening Star, it carried the title "Out Where the Worst Begins."

Scopenote: Renovation work on the South Portico of the White House.

Truman would not allow a hole large enough to fit the bulldozer to be cut into the walls of the White House.

title: South view in the Family Dining Room during White House renovation
Scopenote: South view in the Family Dining Room during White House renovation.  When the vaulted ceiling, installed by McKim, Mead and White in 1902, was removed, the red and white wall paper on the old ceiling was revealed.

title: Photograph of upper part of main stairway of the White House during renovation
Scopenote: Photograph of upper part of main stairway taken from the landing between the first and second floors. The design on the left dates from 1902.  The brick support for the steps, only one layer in thickness, was found to be in an insecure condition.

title: View of west wall of the East Room at doorway to the main corridor of the White House during renovation
Scopenote: View of west wall of the East Room at doorway to the main corridor of the White House during renovation.  The design above the doorway dates from 1902. The iron above the doorway and the brickwork around it were installed in 1902.

title: West view in lower corridor of the White House during renovation
Scopenote: West view in lower corridor of the White House during renovation. The curved iron bands supported the vaulted ceiling installed in 1902.

title: East Wall of the State Dining Room of the White House During the Renovation
Scopenote: East wall of the State Dining Room with doorways into the Red Room.  The design above, uncovered when the oak paneling was removed, dates from 1902.  The old fireplace, bricked up since 1902,is also seen.

title: Northwest view in the Social Room of the White House during renovation
Scopenote: Northwest view in the  Social Room of the White House during renovation. The old design on the wall, uncovered during the renovation work, dates from 1902.

title: Northeast view in Room 11 during White House renovation
Scopenote: Northeast view in Room 11 during White House renovation.  The water pipes were encased in the brick flue which extended from basement to top of building.

title: North Wall of the State Dining Room of the White House During Renovation
Scopenote: North wall of the State Dining Room.  The marks on the brick from west to east are an old stairway. In the opposite direction, the holes for supports of the later stairway, removed in 1902,can be seen.

title: North view of east side of the second floor of White House during renovation
Scopenote: White House renovation, north view of east side of the second floor from the Lincoln Room looking through East Sitting Room into Rose Room and small bedroom on right.

title: View of north front of the White House during renovation
Scopenote: View of north front of the White House. The Seneca stone wall east of the North Portico has been removed and excavation begun to remove water pipes preparatory to enlarging storage area under the lawn.  The temporary cable carries electricity from one wing to the other.

title: Official Photographer of the White House Renovation
Scopenote: The official photographs of the renovation of the White House are being taken by Abbie Rowe, photographer, National Park Service, Department of the Interior.  Mr. Rowe and the equipment used by him in this work are shown in this photograph.

title: Southwest view showing the members and officials
Scopenote: Southwest view showing the members and officials of the Fine Arts Commission in front of the South Portico. The Commission oversees the work on the White House.

title: View of North Hall of 3rd Floor Corridor during renovation of the White House
Scopenote: View of North Hall of 3rd Floor Corridor from the steps of the Sun Parlor on the south, taken during the renovation of the White House.  From the temporary steel beams in the foreground, across the steel beams of the 3rd Floor, tie-rods were installed to hold up the 2nd Floor below.

title: Members and officials of the Fine Arts Commission on the roof of the White House
Scopenote: Members and officials of the Commission on the roof above the South Portico of the White House. They oversee the renovation work. The view is to the southeast.

title: View of entire third floor corridor during renovation of White House
Scopenote: View of entire third floor corridor looking east, during the renovation of the White House.  The walls and ceilings of the rooms, except around the elevator areaway, have been removed leaving only the structural steel framework.

title: Fine Arts Commission members and officials in the Blue Room of the White House during renovation
Scopenote: Fine Arts Commission members and officials in the Blue Room viewing pieces of the old Cornice of the ceiling in the Main Corridor which are being preserved, during the renovation of the White House.  The old Cornice was revealed when the false ceiling, installed in 1902, was removed.

title: The members and officials of the Fine Arts Commission, who oversee the renovation of the White House
Scopenote: The members and officials of the Fine Arts Commission inspecting the excavation and underpinning work to the west of the South Portico of the White House during renovation.

title: View of the west side of the storage building during the renovation of the White House
Scopenote: View of the west side of the storage building on the south lawn of the White House during inspection by the Commission members and officials who oversee the renovation of the White House.

title: View of the north wall and second floor joists, during renovation of White House
Scopenote: View of the north wall and second floor joists after the lath and plaster was removed from the ceiling of the Family Dining Room during the renovation of the White House.  Clamps were installed to hold the cracked beam late in 1948.

title: Photograph of west wall of the Family Dining Room, during renovation of the White House
Scopenote: Photograph of west wall of the Family Dining Room after plaster was removed showing studding dating from 1815-1818.  Beyond the studding is the pantry (below) and the mezzanine (above). This photo was taken during the renovation of the White House.

title: Northeast View from 2nd Floor Corridor, White House During Renovation
Scopenote: Northeast view from 2nd Floor Corridor to Room 14, North Hall and Room 15.  The four temporary steel shoring columns have been installed from concrete foundation 30 feet below grade to support the large 40 foot horizontal beams below the 3rd Floor level.

title: Northeast view from first floor corridor to the Lobby, during renovation of White House
Scopenote: Northeast view from first floor corridor to the lobby, during the White House renovation.  The four temporary steel shoring columns installed on concrete foundations 30 feet below grade go through the Lobby to the third Floor level.

title: Southwest view in the State Dining Room of the White House during renovation
Scopenote: Southwest view in the State Dining Room of the White House during renovation.  The temporary wooden beams were installed to support the second floor above.

title: Second Floor Oval Study Above Blue Room During the White House Renovation
Scopenote: Two unidentified men stand in what remains of the second floor Oval Study above the Blue Room. The north wall and part of the floor have been removed for the installation of steel shoring columns.

title: South view in main stairway of White House during renovation
Scopenote: South view in main stairway of White House during renovation, from scaffold on level of landing between first and second floors.  The steps and brick supports of second floor stairs have been removed, and only the supports of basement stairs remain.

title: West view of entire length of the lower corridor during renovation of White House
Scopenote: West view of entire length of the lower corridor during the renovation of the White House.  The shoring columns in the foreground to the first floor are permanent, while the columns beyond are temporary.  The extension of these columns to the third floor will be temporary to support the roof during construction.

Scopenote: North view from Blue Room of the White House during renovation, elevated to second and third floor corridors and skylight. title: Southwest view in the Family Dining Room during renovation of White House
Scopenote: Southwest view in the Family Dining Room with the Pantry on the right during renovation of the White House.  The arches of the basement ceiling are seen in the foreground.

Scopenote: North view of upper wall and ceiling in the Usher's Office during White House renovation.  The ceiling is covered with colored Dutch metal.  This and the cornice design date from 1902.

title: Photograph along west side of roof during White House renovation
Scopenote: Photograph along west side of roof taken from the southwest corner and looking north, during the renovation of the White House. Workmen can be seen.

Scopenote: View of top of White House roof from the west to the State Department on the east, during renovation.

Scopenote: View of south wall of the Doctor's Office showing progress in completion of concrete underpinning columns during the renovation of the White House.

Scopenote: Stuart Symington (center) presenting the pen used by President Richard Nixon in signing the bill changing the name of Kaysinger Dam to Truman Dam into law, to Philip C. Brooks, Director of the Truman Library. Jay B. Dillingham is at left.
